unprepossessing.sentence_1: World leaders coming to meet Gandhi would expect a towering sage, and often would be surprised by the unprepossessing little man dressed only in a loincloth and shawl.
unprepossessing.meaning_1: adjective: creating an unfavorable or neutral first impression

inanity.sentence_1: Bill's poem was nothing more than a list of impressive sounding words, so there was no point in trying to take meaning from the inanity.
inanity.meaning_1: noun: total lack of meaning or ideas

nettlesome.sentence_1: Maria found her coworker's cell phone nettlesome, because every few minutes it would buzz to life with another text message.

baleful.sentence_1: Movies often use storms or rain clouds as a baleful omen of evil events that will soon befall the main character.
baleful.meaning_1: adjective: threatening or foreshadowing evil or tragic developments

artifice.sentence_1: The mayoral candidates both spent much of the campaign accusing each other of artifices designed to mislead the voting public.
artifice.meaning_1: noun: cunning tricks used to deceive others

empiricism.sentence_1: Empiricism does not always lead to knowledge; an experience or experiment may raise more questions than it answers.
empiricism.meaning_1: noun: any method that derives knowledge from experience, used in experimental science as a way to gain insight and knowledge

hoary.sentence_1: Most workout gurus are young, fit people, whereas most yoga gurus are hoary men with long white beards.

languish.sentence_1: Stranded in the wilderness for four days, the hiker languished, eating protein bars and nuts.

ineffable.sentence_1: While art critics can occasionally pinpoint a work's greatness, much of why a piece captures our imaginations is completely ineffable.
ineffable.meaning_1: adjective: too sacred to be uttered; defying expression or description

doleful.sentence_1: No event is more doleful than the passing of my mother; she was a shining star in my life, and it brings me great sadness to think that she is now gone.
doleful.meaning_1: adjective: filled with or evoking sadness

bristle.sentence_1: As we discussed the painting, I noticed the artist's wife bristling at our criticisms, ready to defend her husband's work.
bristle.meaning_1: verb: react in an offended or angry manner

unstinting.sentence_1: Helen is unstinting with her time, often spending hours at the house of a sick friend.

recrudesce.sentence_1: After years of gamblers anonymous, Tony thought he'd broken his compulsive slot machine playing, but it took only one trip to the Atlantic City for a full recrudescence--he lost $5k on the one armed bandit.
recrudesce.meaning_1: verb: to break out or happen again

disingenuous.sentence_1: Many adults think that they can lie to children, but kids are smart and know when people are disingenuous.
disingenuous.meaning_1: adjective: not straightforward; giving a false appearance of frankness

chagrin.sentence_2: She never cared what others said about her appearance but was chagrined by the smallest comment from her mother.
chagrin.sentence_1: Much to the timid writer's chagrin, the audience chanted his name until he came back on the stage.
chagrin.meaning_2: verb: cause to feel shame; hurt the pride of

antic.sentence_1: The clown's antic act was too extreme for the youngest children, who left the room in tears.
antic.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study

rapprochement.sentence_1: Although Ann hoped that her mother and her aunt would have a rapprochement, each one's bitter accusations against the other made any reconciliation unlikely.
rapprochement.meaning_1: noun: the reestablishing of cordial relations

browbeat.sentence_1: During the interrogation, the suspect was browbeaten into signing a false confession.
browbeat.meaning_1: verb: be bossy towards; discourage or frighten with threats or a domineering manner

arrogate.sentence_1: Arriving at the small town, the outlaw arrogated the privileges of a lord, asking the frightened citizens to provide food, drink, and entertainment.
arrogate.meaning_1: verb: seize and control without authority

apothegm.sentence_1: Winston Churchill is famous for many apothegms, but this might be his most famous: "It has been said that democracy is the worst form of government except all the others that have been tried."
apothegm.meaning_1: noun: a short, pithy instructive saying

reprisal.sentence_1: The Old Testament doctrine of "an eye for an eye" would seem to justify an immediate physical reprisal for any injury, but that interpretation neglects the many passages that value mercy and loving-kindness over revenge.
reprisal.meaning_1: noun: a retaliatory action against an enemy in wartime

chimera.sentence_1: Many believe that a world free of war is a chimera—a dream that ignores humanity's violent tendencies.
chimera.meaning_1: noun: something desired or wished for but is only an illusion and impossible to achieve

ersatz.sentence_1: The car dealer's ersatz laughter was immediately followed by a price quote, one that Shelley found highly inflated.
ersatz.meaning_1: adjective: not real or genuine; phony

exemplar.sentence_1: Lena's homework is on the wall because it is an exemplar of clean, neat, and thoughtful work.

paragon.sentence_2: Some say that Athens was the paragon of democracy, but these people often forget that slaves and women were still not allowed to vote.
paragon.sentence_1: Even with the rise of Kobe Bryant, many still believe that Michael Jordon is the paragon for basketball players.
paragon.meaning_1: noun: model of excellence or perfection of a kind; one having no equal
paragon.meaning_2: noun: an ideal instance; a perfect embodiment of a concept

appurtenant.sentence_1: In hiking Mt. Everest, sherpas are appurtenant, helping climbers both carry gear and navigate treacherous paths.

effervescent.sentence_1: After the sales result, the manager was in an effervescent mood, letting several employees leave work early that day.
effervescent.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
effervescent.meaning_1: adjective: marked by high spirits or excitement

vitriol.sentence_1: His vitriol spewed forth from a deep-seated racism that consumed his whole life.
vitriol.meaning_1: noun: abusive or venomous language used to express blame or bitter deep-seated ill will

epigram.sentence_1: My favorite epigram from Mark Twain is "A man who carries a cat by the tail learns something he can learn no other way."

solicitude.sentence_1: I walked to his house in the rain to make sure he had enough to eat while he was sick, but he seemed not to appreciate my solicitude.
solicitude.meaning_1: noun: a feeling of excessive concern

besotted.sentence_2: Never before have I seen my mom so besotted, and honestly, I hope it's the last time she drinks so much.
besotted.sentence_1: Even though her father did not approve, Juliet became besotted with the young Romeo.

broadside.sentence_1: Political broadsides are usually strongest in the weeks leading up to a national election.

philistine.sentence_1: Jane considered Al completely philistine, because he talked almost exclusive about video games; she was entirely unaware of how well read he really was.
philistine.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
philistine.meaning_1: adjective: smug and ignorant towards artistic and cultural values

percipient.sentence_1: Even the most percipient editor will make an occasional error when proofreading.

phlegmatic.sentence_1: Arnold is truly noble, remaining reserved until an issue of significance arises, but Walter is simply phlegmatic: he doesn't have the energy or inclination to care about anything.

untrammeled.sentence_1: The whole notion of living untrammeled inspired the American Revolution and was enshrined in the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution.

debonair.sentence_1: James Bond is known for his good looks, high tech gadgets, and debonair manner.

anachronism.sentence_1: Dressed in 15th century clothing each day, Edward was a walking anachronism.
anachronism.meaning_1: noun: something that is inappropriate for the given time period (usually something old).

truculence.sentence_1: When the boss confronted Aaron about his earlier remarks, Aaron responded with utter truculence, simply throwing a glass of water in the boss' face and walking away.

brook.sentence_1: While she was at the chalkboard, the teacher did not brook any form of talking--even a tiny peep resulted in afternoon detention.
brook.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
brook.meaning_1: verb: put up with something or somebody unpleasant

deign.sentence_1: The master of the house never deigned to answer questions from the servants.
deign.meaning_1: verb: do something that one considers to be below one's dignity

objurgate.sentence_1: The manager spent an hour objurgating the employee in the hopes that he would not make these mistakes again.

meteoric.sentence_1: The early spectacular successes propelled the pitcher to meteoric stardom, but a terrible injury tragically cut short his career.
meteoric.meaning_1: adjective: like a meteor in speed or brilliance or transience

pith.sentence_1: When Cynthia hears a speaker presenting a complex argument, she is always able to discard the irrelevant details and extract the pith of what the speaker is trying to convey.
pith.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
pith.meaning_1: noun: the most essential part of something

bemoan.sentence_1: While the CFO carefully explained all the reasons for the cuts in benefits, after the meeting employees bemoaned the cuts as further evidence that management was against them.
bemoan.meaning_1: verb: express discontent or a strong regret

inchoate.sentence_1: Inchoate ideas about the relation of humans to other animals had been discussed since the Middle Ages but the modern theory really began with Darwin.
inchoate.meaning_1: adjective: only partly in existence; imperfectly formed

atavism.sentence_1: Much of the modern art movement was an atavism to a style of art found only in small villages through Africa and South America.
atavism.meaning_1: noun: a reappearance of an earlier characteristic; throwback

embryonic.sentence_1: The Board of Directors is hoping to launch a new product soon, but planning for the Z7 is in an embryonic stage.
embryonic.meaning_1: adjective: in an early stage of development

gambit.sentence_1: Randy played a gambit, telling his boss that he would leave at the end of the week if he didn't get a raise.
gambit.meaning_1: noun: a maneuver or risk in a game or conversation, designed to secure an advantage

squelch.sentence_1: After the dictator consolidated his power, he took steps to squelch all criticism, often arresting any journalist who said anything that could be interpreted as negative about his regime.
